s.text: and even along the driveway my poor little spindly pear trees have devised a few blossoms, at one of which I saw a sleepy bee bumbling, my first bee.

But Updike, even in this book, is a great writer, the greatest we have, in his particular areas of strength--in the control of visual details, in his rhythmic intensity, in the colors and shapes that come pouring syncopatedly from his mischievous pen.
Driving out to Route 128, I see a weeping cherry tree, no less spectacular for being familiar, making its annual splash of purple-pink ...
Driving out to Route 128, I see a weeping cherry tree, no less spectacular for being familiar, making its annual splash of purple-pink ...
Toward the End of Time might seem different from his other novels because of the sci-fi trappings, which do get rather fantastic.

But Updike, even in this book, is a great writer, the greatest we have, in his particular areas of strength--in the control of visual details, in his rhythmic intensity, in the colors and shapes that come pouring syncopatedly from his mischievous pen.

But Updike, even in this book, is a great writer, the greatest we have, in his particular areas of strength--in the control of visual details, in his rhythmic intensity, in the colors and shapes that come pouring syncopatedly from his mischievous pen.
